flow.context: Lucia Macklis is the Operations Manager at Oranj Palm Vacation Homes (OPVH), the vacation rental arm of Palm Springs Rental Agency — a Coachella Valley operator since 1972 managing 100–300 properties. As Ops Manager she owns turnover execution, cleaner workflows, and QA bottlenecks daily. They use Track PMS and have a dedicated QA department and maintenance lines, but no confirmed inspection-photo platform. Strongest Sam connection: both SoCal natives — Lucia was born in San Diego and loves the beach, Sam grew up in LA and surfs. Direct line: 760-406-8606.

gatekeeper_slide.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_slide.say: Hey, could you get me through to Lucia? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_slide.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain. Say it like you know her. If they ask 'Lucia who?' just say 'Lucia Macklis.'

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — GIVE CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other vacation rental operators out in the Coachella Valley. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no pitch. Dose info bit by bit. If they ask the company name say 'RapidEye — she might not recognize it, I just wanted to follow up on something.' If this is Brenda Lopez the Executive Assistant, use her name naturally.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally fair — we help a couple other property management companies with their inspection and turnover workflows. I sent her a note, just wanted to give her a heads up. Would you mind passing me through?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last shot. If blocked, get a callback time or leave a message. If this is Brenda say 'Brenda, appreciate you — would you mind just letting her know I called?'

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL OR LEFT MESSAGE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: Hey Lucia, it's Sam Parks — I work with a few vacation rental operators similar to Oranj Palm on their turnover inspection workflows. Wanted to run something by you real quick. My number is [your number]. Again, Sam Parks. Talk soon.
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Under 20 seconds. Sound casual, don't pitch. Call back in 2 days if no response. Also email Lucia@oranjpalm.com with a short note.

opener.label: OPENER — LUCIA PICKS UP
opener.say: Hey Lucia — I work with a few other vacation rental ops teams out in the desert. I'm originally from LA so I know the valley pretty well. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: SoCal connection is authentic — Sam grew up in La Cañada, Lucia was born in San Diego. Feet up on the desk energy. Don't rush. Pause after 'tossed around' and let her respond.

branches.label: Is this a sales call? / What do you want?

heard_name_no.label: HEARD NAME — NO
heard_name_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_name_no.note: Transition immediately into pain trigger. Don't dwell. Keep the energy light and move.

heard_name_yes.label: HEARD NAME — YES
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you on the ops side. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge with 'Yeah exactly — that's actually why I'm calling.' Then go to pain trigger.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — I know you're probably in the thick of it right now with season ramping up out there. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday when things settle a bit?
bad_timing.note: February is peak season in Palm Springs — Modernism Week, events, back-to-back turnovers. She's legitimately slammed. Get a specific callback day and time.

schedule_callback.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
schedule_callback.say: Perfect — I'll call you then. Really appreciate it, Lucia. Talk soon.
schedule_callback.note: Write down the exact time. When you call back open with: 'Hey Lucia, it's Sam Parks — you told me to call you back today. Appreciate you making time.'

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION — ASK FOR 30 SECONDS
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: This resets the dynamic. You acknowledged reality. Most people give you the 30 seconds. If yes go straight to pain trigger and keep it tight.

branches.label: No / not interested / don't call me

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — SPLIT THE OBJECTION
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it more that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Multiple-choice question. Re-engages without pushing. 'Horrible time' means book a callback. 'Not interesting' opens the door to clarify what you actually do.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — THE PROBLEM
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another ops manager at a vacation rental company pretty similar to yours — about a hundred-something properties in a resort market, big seasonal swings. And the thing that was eating her alive was the turnover photo review. Her cleaners were snapping photos after every clean, but with back-to-back flips — like three turns on the same property during festival week — nobody actually had bandwidth to look through them all. So stuff was slipping. A cracked pool tile here, a missing blender there, cigarette burn on a patio cushion. And they wouldn't find out until a guest left a one-star review or an owner called asking why their couch has a stain on it. The photos were there the whole time — they just couldn't humanly review that volume. Does any of that sound familiar, or is your world totally different?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after the question. This is the most important silence on the call. She runs QA and turnovers across 100+ Coachella Valley properties — this pain is real, especially mid-season. If she starts sharing her own version she is warm. Listen.

branches.label: Yes / that's exactly us / tells her own story
We actually handle that pretty well
I'm not really the right person for this

warm_react.label: SHE'S FEELING THE PAIN
warm_react.say: Yeah, I hear that a lot. So what does that actually look like for you guys right now? Like, are your cleaners taking photos after every turn, or is it more of a spot-check situation?
warm_react.note: STOP PITCHING. She's warm — ask questions and listen. The more she describes problems the more she sells herself on needing a solution. Let her talk.

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Got it. And when those photos come in — who's actually reviewing them? Is that you, or does your QA team handle that?
discovery_process.note: You know they have a QA department (QA@oranjpalm.com) and Henry Sauceda in maintenance/QA. Ask about the real workflow. You want to understand: who reviews, how many photos, what gets missed, what happens when something slips.

discovery_dig.label: DISCOVERY — DIG DEEPER
discovery_dig.say: That makes sense. With a hundred-plus properties out there and back-to-back turns, what's been the biggest headache? Like is it more the volume of photos nobody has time for, or is it more that stuff gets missed and then you hear about it from the owner?
discovery_dig.note: Both answers are good for you. 'Volume' — RapidEye solves it. 'Owner complaints' — even more urgent. Mirror back whatever she picks. If she mentions owner complaints pivot to solution_bridge_owners.

solution_bridge.label: SOLUTION — ONE LINER
solution_bridge.say: That's exactly what we built this for. So RapidEye plugs right into Track — I saw you guys are on Track — and it automatically analyzes every turnover photo your team's already taking. Catches damage, missing items, staging issues — the stuff a human would catch if they had time to actually look at every single photo. No workflow change for your cleaners at all.
solution_bridge.note: One-sentence solution then pivot to CTA. Don't oversell. Don't demo on the phone. Naming Track specifically shows you did homework. If she asks 'how does it work' — say 'that's exactly what I'd walk you through, can I show you?'

branches.label: We'd need to talk to leadership

solution_bridge_owners.label: SOLUTION — OWNER ANGLE
solution_bridge_owners.say: Yeah and that's the worst part — you've got the homeowner liaison team fielding calls from owners about stuff that could've been caught during the turn. So what we built plugs into Track and automatically flags damage, missing items, anything off — in the photos your cleaners are already taking. Before the next guest walks in. Before the owner ever finds out.
solution_bridge_owners.note: You know Sue Kennelly is the homeowner liaison. Don't name-drop her unless it flows naturally. This framing hits Lucia's pain: she's the one whose team gets blamed when owners complain. Pivot to CTA.

cta_meeting.label: CTA — ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to seeing how it actually works? I could show you with photos from a real turnover — takes about twenty minutes. When I'm not cold calling you out of the blue.
cta_meeting.note: Low friction. 'Twenty minutes' is specific and small. If she asks about cost say 'Totally fair, that's one of the first things I'd walk through. Can I show you the whole picture on a quick call this week?'

branches.label: Sure / yeah let's set it up
I don't have budget right now
I'd need to loop in my GM or VP

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect — I've got next week pulled up. How does Tuesday or Wednesday look? I'm flexible on time.
book_meeting.note: Pick two days. Get a specific time. Send the invite WHILE on the phone. If she wants to include Alexander or Karlos great — ask for their email. Once booked STOP SELLING.

branches.label: Not sure / let me check my calendar

meeting_pin_down.label: PIN DOWN THE TIME
meeting_pin_down.say: Totally — how about I shoot you the invite for Tuesday at ten and you can move it if you need to? That way it's on the books and you don't have to think about it. Is Lucia at oranjpalm dot com the best email?
meeting_pin_down.note: An invite on the calendar is 5x more likely to happen than 'I'll email you times.' Don't let it float. Confirm the email.

branches.label: Just email me and I'll confirm

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED — CLOSE
meeting_booked.say: Awesome — sending that over right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Lucia. I'll keep it tight and make it worth your twenty minutes. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Send calendar invite immediately. Add a short note in the invite body: 'Will show you how it works with real turnover photos — keeping it to 20 min.' Follow up 24 hours before with a quick confirmation email or text.

loop_in_leadership.label: NEEDS LEADERSHIP BUY-IN
loop_in_leadership.say: That makes total sense. Who would you want in the room — would that be Karlos or Alexander? Happy to set it up with them on the line so you're not doing double the work.
loop_in_leadership.note: Karlos Salinas is VP, Alexander Vega is GM. Drop first names naturally. If she confirms one offer to send the invite to both. If she wants to talk to them first offer to send her something she can forward.

branches.label: Let me talk to them first

obj_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
obj_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that turnover quality just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Because I get it either way.
obj_not_interested.note: Agree first then split the objection. 'Hate cold calls' is a format objection not a product objection — pivot to value. 'Not focused on this' — ask what IS the priority and look for a hook.

branches.label: Not a priority / focused on other things

obj_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
obj_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a hundred-plus properties you'd have to have something in place. Totally respect that. Is it more that you're fully covered and everything's airtight, or is it more that switching anything right now — especially mid-season — would just be a headache?
obj_have_process.note: It's February in Palm Springs — peak season. She won't rip out a process right now. But if she says 'bad timing to switch' that's a future opportunity. If she says 'we're covered' ask what tool or process they use — intel is valuable either way.

branches.label: We're covered / happy with our process
Bad timing to change anything mid-season
Tells you what tool or process they use

obj_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
obj_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's hard enough to keep a tool let alone buy something new. Is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy has to go through Thomas and the whole approval process?
obj_no_budget.note: Thomas Salinas is President and controls financial oversight. Dropping his first name shows you understand the org. If budget cycle issue book a meeting for when budget opens. If approval chain issue offer to help build the case.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally hear you — you're probably not buying anything today and I respect that. But if nothing else I could walk you through what a couple other PM companies in the Coachella Valley are doing with their turnover photos right now. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to a quick twenty minutes?
sell_test_drive.note: The offer of value: even if she never buys, the meeting gives her intel on what competitors are doing. That is worth her time. If she bites go to book_meeting. If not graceful close.

sell_test_drive_seasonal.label: TEST DRIVE — SEASONAL ANGLE
sell_test_drive_seasonal.say: Makes total sense — I wouldn't want you touching anything mid-season either. What if we set something up for after things cool down? Like early March? That way you've got it on the radar before summer planning kicks in and you're not dealing with it while you're slammed with turnovers.
sell_test_drive_seasonal.note: Palm Springs peak starts cooling as desert temps rise in late April. March is still busy but slightly less intense. Frame this as strategic planning not a fire drill.

obj_send_email.label: OBJECTION — SEND ME AN EMAIL
obj_send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question so it's actually useful and not just another generic pitch — is it more the operational side you'd want to see, like how it works with Track day-to-day, or more the business case for what it saves your team?
obj_send_email.note: Ask what to include so the email is tailored. Confirm her email: 'Is Lucia at oranjpalm dot com the best one?' Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email. Follow up in 3 days if no response.

branches.label: Tells you what she wants to see

email_close.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — CLOSE
email_close.say: Got it — I'll have that over to you today. And I'll throw a couple times on there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you look it over. Appreciate your time, Lucia.
email_close.note: Send the email within 1 hour. Subject line should reference Oranj Palm and turnovers specifically. Include a calendar link or 2 specific time options. Follow up by phone in 3 business days if no reply.

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
not_right_person.say: Totally get it — who on your team would typically own something like this? Like is that more of an Alexander or Karlos decision?
not_right_person.note: Alexander Vega is GM, Karlos Salinas is VP. Use first names. If she names someone else roll with it. Get their name and direct line. Offer to send Lucia something she can forward to warm the intro.

referral_get_name.label: GET THE REFERRAL NAME
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — and what's the best way to reach them? If I can get a direct line or email I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't waste their time.
referral_get_name.note: Get name, title, phone, email. If she names Thomas, Karlos, or Alexander you already have their info — confirm it. Then ask: 'Would it help if I mentioned you pointed me their way?'

referral_push.label: PUSH FOR SPECIFIC NAME
referral_push.say: Totally — I just want to make sure it gets to the right person and doesn't end up in a general inbox. Is there one person who'd be the best fit? Even just a first name and I'll figure the rest out.
referral_push.note: Don't accept 'email the main line' — that is a dead end. Push gently for a specific person. If she won't budge accept gracefully and email Karlos@oranjpalm.com directly on your own.

referral_close.label: REFERRAL OBTAINED — CLOSE
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Lucia. I'll reach out to them this week and keep it relevant. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of your day.
referral_close.note: Call the referral within 24 hours. Open with: 'Lucia Macklis on your team pointed me your way — she thought this might be relevant to you.' Send Lucia a short thank-you email same day.

graceful_close.label: GRACEFUL CLOSE
graceful_close.say: Totally understand. If anything changes I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Lucia — enjoy the rest of your week.
graceful_close.note: Don't burn the bridge. Add her to a 60-day follow-up cadence. Try Karlos or Alexander as a separate cold call. Send a non-pushy LinkedIn connect request if you can find her profile.
